很多人心目中的第九艺术的代表作品之一。游戏用出色而又复杂的剧情，美式朋克且光怪陆离的宗教风格混搭，还有出色的角色塑造做出了这个极佳的游戏世界。游戏的战斗部分有点德军总部的感觉，简单而又爽快，但整体元素不多。游戏出色的在于剧情，因为平时看类似元素的电影游戏较多，所以并没有太多疑惑，但是看了一遍解析后还是能感受到更多的味道。游戏塑造的伊丽莎白这个角色也格外有魅力且经典，而且角色的ui也着实可圈可点。总的来说游戏各方面在那个时代简直是全方面的优秀，放在现在体验也极佳，是一部必玩的佳作。
另外两个海葬dlc联系了前作，虽然最后的结局都很压抑，但是整体设计真的很出彩，强烈建议玩两个dlc。

Infinite is the pinnacle of the series. Playing Bioshock 1/2 not required at all to understand and fully enjoy the magnificence of this game. It's a thought-bending, mind-blowing, jaw-dropping experience.

Bioshock Infinite is the result of Ken Levine snorting raw cocaine and thinking "Hey, we should put a city in the sky instead of the ocean." and I'm going to be 100% honest in saying that they pulled it off really well. Gameplay wise, I'd say that Bioshock Infinite excels well past its two predecessors. What were once plazmids are now referred to as "vigors". For the remainder of this review i'm going to call them plazmids because vigor is a fucking stupid name and I don't see why they changed it. The plazmids work in a familiar way to how they worked in Bioshock 2 where they can be used at the same time you're blowing some poor sods brains out with a machine gun. And despite being a OG Bioshock fan I do acknowledge that the system used in its sequels serves the plazmids better and lets you combo different plazmids and weapons easier. The way you restore your Eve or "salt" in this game is very unique to this game in the series so far. Instead of picking up eve hypos and stabbing that shit into your wrist faster than formula 1, you instead have to pick up salt and health packs on the go without being able to store extra. This is a running trend throughout the entirety of Bioshock Infinite. Packing lightly and choosing wisely is a necessity since you can also only carry 2 weapons at a time, which I at first found odd, but I easily adapted to after a while. 

The new weapons and unique plazmids on offer would be nice if I didn't restrict myself to only 3 or 4 plazmids out of necessity. And the hand cannon is just as necessary late game when fighting handymen. I never dropped my hand cannon since getting it off FInk's butler because its so damn useful at both long and short range. Speaking of the handymen, if you haven't played the game heres a tip on how to beat them that I learnt the hard way. Bait them to electrocute the rail before jumping off the rail and unloading everything you have into them. This was one of the only ways I could kill them on hard mode. The rails themselves are one of the best additions to this franchise that I didn't even think I needed. The freedom and mobility they grant you is just amazing and it's so unlike anything we've seen from Ken before that i'm absolutely sure he was on drugs while making this. But what do I think of Elizabeth? Surely having the game be one big escort mission would suck big columbian balls? Well, no. From the beginning the game makes it obvious that Elizabeth doesn't need you to protect her. The enemies don't attack her and she keeps up with the player pretty easily. I never had a problem with her path finding and i've only noticed one instance of when I had to wait up for her. Her ability to find money for you just after you spent all the money you had at a vending machine is sometimes annoying but a minor problem and is well made up for when she hands you health packs and ammo on the battle field. I cannot say how many times a stray health pack or salt container has saved my ass mid fight. Her tears on the other hand put you in control of what you want and when you want it. They work fairly well and are useful for preparing for a fight, as well as being stressful sometimes since you can only open one tear at a time. A good part of this is that there's no cool down so you can switch from one tear to another quickly but they also don't restock so once you use all those precious health packs you'd better high tail it out of there. My one and only major gripe with Bioshock Infinites gameplay is that sometimes I have to many options. I know that sounds like bullshit but hear me out. Having so many different ways to complete something does make the player more likely to become attached to one way of doing it. Half of the plazmids in the game I only used once. A lot of the explosive and one-shot weapons really weren't worth keeping in a slot, and upgrading the guns you have ammo for is always better than not. There is quite a few more things I forgot to cover so i'm going to go over them now. The rechargeable shield mechanic worked well for the most part but I thought that it broke a bit to easily sometimes. The infusion was fine but I don't recommend putting too many points into shield. And the melee mechanics. Comparing the skyhook to the wrench from Bioshock 1 is interesting given that the skyhook is an instant attack while you had to switch to the wrench to use it. I like how when you hit lighter enemies with the skyhook the fumble over leaving an opening to finish them off. I also like how when you finish off an enemy with the skyhook, it plays a horror movie sting. Just something to cement how fucked up some of the finishing moves are. My personal favourite is the one where you snap the enemies neck with the spinny part of the skyhook. Just the right amount of disturbing. And Elizabeths reaction to your senseless brutality is always gold.

I'm not going to go indepth with the story to avoid spoilers for anyone who wants to play this game for themselves. All you need to know is that I think it's alright and it might take a while for it all to make sense if its your first time playing it. And while there are some plot holes, it's easy to look past them. All in all, it's not as tightly written as Bioshock 1 but it's easy to become invested into this world. My whole thought on the capitalist rich and the working class immigrants having extremes on both sides is something you don't see often in this day and age. This is an overall great game and I think a worthy continuation to the Bioshock series ( even though like 90% of the game has nothing to do with the old Bioshock but whatever that's ok ) and I would play 1999 mode if it wasn't rigged. The best way to play this game is probably on hard mode but if you're just starting to play the game, maybe stick to medium or lower. 9/10 good shit.

If you've ever wondered what Bioshock would be like as a generic, oversimplified fps with none of the mechanics that made the first two unique, then this is the game for you. 

     Resource management is almost non existent with the low cost of ammo, infinite wallet, readily available healing items on every corpse, and the endless piles money that constantly flow in. When you take those and add them to the fact that Elizabeth will throw you anything you're low on in the middle of  a fight with only a small cool down, it becomes a bit of a joke.
     
     In what appears to be an attempt to "trim the fat" in the Bioshock's passives system, it seems half the meat was lost as well. The passive ability slots are brought down from Bioshock 2's impressive 18, to a measly 4 in Infinite.

     Hacking as a game feature is gone. A salt heavy vigor known as possession will allow you to take control of one enemy security system for a very limited time, but long term or permanent security allies are non existent. Door security systems and key code locks are replaced with Elizabeth's lock picking abilities. 

     All weapon and vigor upgrades are purchased with money, negating the need to find upgrade stations off the beaten path, or take on challenging enemies such as big daddies. Guns now only have one ammo type, with weapon based traps being removed from the game. Variety is also greatly reduced, with all weapons now falling under the basic pistol, rifle, shotgun, launcher setup you'd see in most fps games.

     The dark, wet, creaking underwater city of Rapture is replaced with a sunny skied Columbia. Gone is the horror aspect, gone are the tight, small corridors, gone are the enemies with motivation, gone is the entire atmosphere this series was built upon. Bioshock Infinite's world introduction is a bland and pretentious mess, filled with the writers thinly veiled hatred of certain groups, while arrogantly claiming to champion others. And then, only a few hours in, they just seem to drop it in the background. It's as if these all these "heavy" issues this game seemed so ready to face head on just no longer mattered to it. The game's attempt to build up it's characters repeatedly falls short. Infinite isn't able to find an organic relationship between Booker and Elizabeth, emotions feels off, closeness feels forced. When it's all said and done the player is left uncomfortably aware that they are sitting in a chair, watching two lumps of pixels stand in an elevator, preparing themselves for the next wave of faceless enemies who will throw themselves at Booker's feet. A sad end to a great series.

我实在不太明白为什么这游戏被吹得那么神？开始我以为是我剧情没走完的原因，但是直到通关我仍然觉得游戏体验感极差。说一下戳我的点吧，伊丽莎白很可爱，而且很难得作为一个npc她不仅不拖后腿还能在战斗的时候随时给你补给（碍事莉，你知道为什么追不上里昂了吗？）游戏场景很精美，刚刚进入哥伦比亚时充满宗教气息的教堂和光影确实让我很惊艳，美式朋克风的天空之城也让人眼前一亮，最后的海中城市、满天星光下的灯塔以及不同时空的伯克和伊丽莎白同时穿梭的场景美得和电影一样。但是除此之外，作为一个游戏它的缺陷也很明显，单一的战斗方式，没有特点的boss，可能制作人员想要把亮点放在不同活素的搭配上，但作为一个普通玩家，感觉从头到尾就是在突突突偶尔放个法术怪就死了，没有任何的成就感，只有不断重复的乏味。支线任务全部是在一个地方找到密码本再在另一个地方破解密码得到一个注能，做不做对剧情毫无影响，那还有设置的必要吗？游戏没有地图，全程只有偶尔会出现bug的指引，加上很多场景其实很类似（比如说反复出现的街道、银行），很容易迷路，再加上你根本不知道下一个存档点在哪里，那种找不到路又不能放弃的感觉真的让人崩溃。本来是很戳我的收集系统，因为地图大且没有任何文字交互提示，只能一点点的逛过相似的场景机械化地按f,最后我甚至懒得收集了，爱爱咋地。最后，是广为称赞的剧情，谁能想到这游戏的字幕还需要自己打开呢？不打开你可能以为npc的对话是bgm…最后的部分确实精彩，轮回和平行时空的设定让人挺意外的，也明白了为什么它命名为无限。但是可能是文化差异，我真的觉得这游戏前面一大部分的剧情挺无聊的，为了体验最后的剧情而走完前面的流程不划算…总之，如果只是想单独买这一部，我个人不推荐，有这钱还不如去买同一个公司出的无主之地。网上很多人说要玩dlc才能体会完整的剧情，但是玩完本体我完全没有买dlc的欲望了.......

真心话，打完之后还是有点懵的，主要是涉及到了平行世界我没太看懂剧情，只知道一个劲地突突突，然后看了一些关于游戏剧情的解读，确实是个很好的游戏，最后是个悲剧么，我不这么认为，这对于主角来说是赎罪，更是解脱。
建议各位在通过之前不要看剧透，在进行人物对话的时候，认真看剧情，不要抓紧那点时间搜东西。最后的结局会给你带来震撼
